text: [Music]
economists call it the leaky bucket
argument if you spend say one pound in a
locally owned shop most of it stays in
the local community but spend it at a
large chain most of it will leave going
to headquarters or shareholders so local
currencies weren't invented as a
solution you can only use them in
locally run shops the idea being to stop
that bucket leaking however their impact
has been minimal but hang on what if
they were run completely on a smartphone
to investigate the idea of local digital
currency I went on a day trip to a city
that is trying it out Liverpool England
my first stop was this deli
watch closely this isn't your typical
purchase it's all being done on mobile
app to app no card reader is needed and
no bank involved either the payment was
made using the local digital currency
this is one of about a hundred
businesses that have signed up the
currency is run by an Israeli company
called colu their rep Leon was my guide
for the day
we're trying to inspire local people to
support their local businesses and
communities help him money to circulate
locally 17,000 people have signed up
since it launched in late 2016
but Liverpool's a big place most people
I asked on the street hadn't heard of it
unlike typical local currencies which
are run not-for-profit colu is a well
financed company out to make money they
do that by charging 1.5% commission when
you convert back to normal currency even
though one local Pound is equal to a
normal UK pound but the advantage for
shops is that they don't have to pay
debit and credit card charges to the
banks
what customers don't realize is even to
pay cash into the bank for a business we
paid to put money in there they
customers probably get their head around
how much we actually pay for banking
well maybe this guy gets it
you're sidestepping the banks but
perhaps overcharging for their carts
herbs and let's let's face it no one's
very fond of in these days are they but
at some point someone has to cash out
paying that 1.5% the deli is fortunate
it can pass it on to one of its main
suppliers this catering company which
has also signed up to the currency
Liverpool Council is considering whether
to accept it I went to meet Liverpool's
assistant mayor who uses the app the
Bristol pound the Liverpool pound the
London pound there are great ideas that
have to be delivered
how can they be delivered that's using
digital currency through secure systems
with people that are innovative he was
keen to stress if the council were to
use colu it would have to be chosen
after an open selection process with
colas official tour over I ventured out
into the city on my own I checked out a
mall for small alternative shops to get
another perspective on this new currency
John Sharkey quits a chain store to set
up his music t-shirt shop at the end of
the day it's just another thing I have
to pay for if I want to get money out of
it I'm not entirely sure my supplies
would accept Kulu because I use a lot of
big supplies that stop businesses like
HMV as well I also hooked up with an
economist who studies local currencies
he sees a problem with colu solution to
the leaky bucket problem bearing in mind
the company isn't based in Liverpool or
even the UK one of the big ironies about
the way that coleauxv sets up the
currency is that they are in fact
extracting money from the local economy
as a design of the currency system they
are immediately taking money outside of
Liverpool which is goes against the
Russian Alfa and local currencies like
uber and delivery
kalo is using venture capital to beef up
its user base giving new joiners free
local money
if it can attract enough users and
become a big player will that mean a
bloody nose for banks and big global
business or will it just mean another
big business taking control of our money
